comments.body: The `StartupTest` will publish start-up metrics to [the dashboard](https://flutter-dashboard.appspot.com/benchmarks.html). I'm not sure these metrics will be useful? Can we add a `reportMetrics` to `StartupTest`'s constructor, default it to `true` and set it to `false` for this test?
No, I don't see the use of them either in this case. :-) Added the flag.
I wonder if the dashboard UI is ready to onboard so many new metrics? :smile:
Hehe. I actually cleaned up the dashboard on Friday and removed all deprecated (dart1) benchmarks.
nit: extract this pattern to a common method

This _is_ the extracted pattern. :-) It's the only occurrence in devicelab, I think.

Unless you mean extract it from the tests... I'm not sure what a clean way to do that would be. I don't really want to put this in `flutter_test`, since it's devicelab-specific...
nit: the param name feels strange to me, maybe just `measureCpuAndGpuUsage`?
`measureCpuAndGpuUsage` was my original name and then I realized a name conflict with `measureCpuAndGpuUsage` method...

This is the line that was changed from https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/46838.
`dart bin/run.dart -t basic_material_app_ios__compile` passes on my machine now.

Here we go again.
https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/46928 was still hard-coding `.app`.  We don't know what it will be called between different perf tests, so find it dynamically.
How about using '--tree-shake-icons' or '--tree-shake-fonts' and Icon/FontTreeShaker everywhere instead of FontSubset?
Done
Maybe hoist this version string to somewhere more visible to make updating easier?
this should be `platform_views_scroll_perf_hybrid_composition` now.  Maybe: `platform_views_hybrid_composition_scroll_perf`
does the test file name matter? The root directory is already different. (now `platform_views_layout_hybrid_composition`)
It would be nice to put your local results in the PR description to set the expectation of those two different flags.
Done.
I had this name wrong in the last PR. Fixed it here.
Why not making `tallky[key]` as `double` to get more precision?
I'm keeping the same datatypes as before to avoid breakage.  With how big these numbers are 1/3 of a number is inconsequential.
I think this shouldn't have been changed like this because e2e tests don't yet have support for CPU/GPU/memory measurements.

Thanks for spotting this! Previously all e2e tests were either Android or gallery. Android disabled CPU/GPU/memory anyway, and Gallery has https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/70438 (which gets discovered today thanks to this).

Uploaded https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/70439 to fix this.

    this.testDriver =  'test_driver/e2e_test.dart',

comments.body: This test takes a while to execute, are you sure you want to run it 15 times?  I think it probably takes at least 1-2 minutes.

Yes, I checked the build dashboard and here's what I observed and expected (as documented in the PR/commit description)
> Currently, a startup test runs for about 1 minute. After the change, the
test should run for about 5 minutes or less because some setup steps
don't need to be repeated 5 times.
Do we need this in the other `run` spots in this file (like `_launchApp`)?

The `_launchApp` is only used by memory test and `--purge-persistent-cache` shouldn't affect it much.

However, in general I agree that adding `--purge-persistent-cache` would make the test more robust just in case that some strange interactions may happen in the future. Even better, I was hoping to have a `--force-reinstall` flag so other stuff could also be cleared.

For this specific flaky situation, I'd like to land this PR first and check if the flakiness is fixed as expected. After that, we can either add `--purge-persistent-cache` to more places, or add `--force-reinstall`.
BTW, for adding more `--purge-persistent-cache` in the future, I'll probably add one flag at a time just to make sure that there's no unexpected performance changes caused by this flag.

comments.body:
\cc @liyuqian re: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/67147
Upping from 3 and then 15 significantly increased the amount of time it took this test to run.

We also suspect it's the cause for the temp storage filling up on Android (hence the uninstall at the end of every loop).
This also needs to apply to the startup test and whatever the SkSL test is
Done.
